questions.text: A previously healthy 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of diarrhea and abdominal cramps since the previous evening. She has had around 3–4 episodes of watery stools. She feels nauseated and has vomited twice. She recollects eating out 2 days ago. She has been on a vegan diet for 6 months. She takes no medications and has not traveled anywhere recently. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica causes yersiniosis, which may also manifest with nausea and diarrhea 0–6 days following ingestion of contaminated milk or pork. However, yersiniosis typically causes bloody diarrhea, fever, and abdominal tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which may mimic appendicitis. Also, this patient is vegan, meaning she does not consume animal products, making infection with Y. enterocolitica unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Shigella dysenteriae causes shigellosis, which may also manifest with diarrhea 1–3 days after ingestion of contaminated food or water. However, shigellosis typically leads to enteric inflammation, mucosal damage, and mucoid-bloody diarrhea. Patients also usually have a fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common organism causing food poisoning due to ingestion of preformed exotoxins that S. aureus produces in contaminated food (e.g., canned meats, mayonnaise). However, S. aureus typically causes a rapid onset of nausea and vomiting 1–6 hours after ingestion. This patient predominantly presents with diarrhea and her symptoms have only started one day after eating out.

D) INCORRECT:

While rotavirus gastroenteritis may also manifest with vomiting, diarrhea, and malaise after an incubation period of 1–3 days, it is usually associated with fever, more severe watery diarrhea (> 10 watery stools within 24 hours), and dehydration. Moreover, rotavirus infection is much more common in infants and children in countries that have not adopted universal use of rotavirus vaccines.

E) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea, which can be acquired when traveling to countries or regions with poor water and food hygiene. While ETEC may also manifest with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, nausea, and possibly vomiting after an incubation period of 9 hours to 3 days, this patient does not have a history of recent travel.

F) INCORRECT:

Salmonella enteritidis can invade the intestinal mucosa in infected individuals and cause salmonellosis, which may also manifest with watery stools, nausea, and vomiting after an incubation period of about 6–48 hours. However, salmonellosis is usually associated with high-grade fever and inflammatory (watery-bloody) diarrhea, which are absent in this patient. Because S. enteritidis is typically transmitted via ingestion of poultry, poorly pasteurized eggs, and milk, infection with this organism is unlikely in this vegan patient who does not consume animal products.

G) CORRECT:

Acute-onset nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and moderate watery, nonbloody diarrhea are consistent with norovirus infection, which is the most common cause of adult gastroenteritis (see “Overview of pathogens causing watery and bloody diarrhea” table). Symptoms typically develop after an incubation period of 12–48 hours. Norovirus is transmitted fecal‑orally; the patient might have contracted the illness from consuming contaminated food or water or from contact with contaminated surfaces. Person-to-person or airborne-droplet transmission is also possible. Because the virus is highly virulent, infected individuals are highly contagious during the acute phase and up to 72 hours following the onset of symptoms.

Diagnosis of norovirus infection is usually clinical; diagnostic studies are not required because confirmation does not affect management. Norovirus infection is self-limiting and symptoms typically resolve after 48–72 hours. Treatment is supportive (e.g., fluid replacement, antiemetics).

H) INCORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus can be transmitted through ingestion of undercooked seafood (e.g., contaminated oysters) and may also cause vomiting and diarrhea. However, this patient is vegan (which means she does not consume animal products), suggesting an infection with a different organism.

I) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus is a common source of food poisoning after ingestion of poorly refrigerated foods, most typically rice. B. cereus produces heat-stable enterotoxin I, which leads to nausea and vomiting 1–3 hours after ingestion of food even if the food is heated. It also produces heat-labile enterotoxin II, which leads to watery diarrhea 8–16 hours after ingestion of food that is not properly reheated. The time frame of both toxins does not correspond to this patient's symptoms, which developed 24 hours after eating out. Furthermore, the patient does not report eating reheated or refrigerated food (e.g., rice).
questions.hint: This organism is known to cause community outbreaks of gastroenteritis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department (ED) with vomiting and diarrhea. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
He reports that about 48 hours ago, he attended an event at his daughter’s preschool, where he consumed a variety of prepared foods. He initially felt well, but about 36 hours after the event (12 hours ago), he started to develop generalized malaise, a fever of 38.4°C, severe vomiting, and several episodes of nonbloody loose stools.
While in the ED, he receives an email from the school principal stating that more than 30 children, parents, and teachers have reported similar gastrointestinal symptoms during the past 24 hours.
Which one of the following pathogens is the most probable cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastroenteritis from the preformed toxins Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus cereus are unlikely, as their incubation periods are less than 24 hours.

B) CORRECT:

Noroviruses account for >90% of acute gastroenteritis outbreaks in the United States. Characterized by a median incubation period of 24 to 48 hours and abrupt onset of symptoms, noroviruses typically manifest with vomiting and moderate, noninflammatory diarrhea. Fever is present in nearly half of cases. Attack rates are high, given the presence of abundant viral particles in both stool and vomitus, the low inoculum required to produce infection, and the persistence of virus on environmental surfaces.

Key learning point: Acute gastroenteritis episodes that have an incubation period of 24 to 48 hours and are characterized by abrupt onset of vomiting and moderate, noninflammatory diarrhea are usually caused by noroviruses.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastroenteritis from the preformed toxins Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus cereus are unlikely, as their incubation periods are less than 24 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Diarrhea due to Clostridioides difficile generally follows antibiotic administration.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroenteritis due to Shigella spp. typically presents with frequent low-volume bloody stools and tenesmus; nausea and vomiting are usually absent.

questions.text:
A healthy, fully immunized 10-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 days after he experienced sudden onset of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis and nonbloody diarrhea. His emesis has largely resolved, but his diarrhea persists. His parents describe the diarrhea as large, watery, foul-smelling stools that occur up to 15 times per day. The boy has had one day of fever, with a maximum temperature of 39.0°C. His 4-year-old brother had similar symptoms approximately one week ago. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
The patient’s current temperature is 38.7°C, his heart rate is 140 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. He is a fatigued, fussy infant who appears ill but is arousable and consolable. He is making tears, but his mucous membranes are dry. His peripheral pulses are strong, and he has a 2-second capillary refill. His abdomen produces hyperactive bowel sounds, is soft, and has no detectable masses.
Which one of the following pathogens is most likely to be responsible for this child’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giardia is a protozoal infection transmitted through contaminated water sources and direct person-to-person contact. Affected patients usually experience cramping and a few bulky, foul-smelling, nonbloody stools a day; less commonly, they may have emesis as a presenting feature.

B) CORRECT:

This boy has typical symptoms of acute viral gastroenteritis, including acute vomiting and nonbloody, watery, voluminous, malodorous diarrhea. Rotavirus was once the most common cause of viral gastroenteritis, but with widespread use of the rotavirus vaccine, that title now belongs to norovirus. Norovirus is the most commonly recognized cause of acute gastroenteritis in the United States among children younger than age 18 months.

In children with norovirus infection, vomiting usually subsides within 2 to 3 days, but the diarrhea may continue for days. Both norovirus and rotavirus are easily transmitted: Carriers shed large amounts of virus for an extended period, and only a small amount of virus is needed for contagion. Other pathogens, including bacteria and parasites, can also cause gastroenteritis, but this child’s symptoms are most consistent with a viral gastroenteritis.

Key learning point: In an otherwise healthy infant, the pathogen most likely to cause nonbloody, nonbilious emesis that progresses to voluminous, watery, nonbloody diarrhea is norovirus.

C) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni, a common cause of bacterial gastroenteritis, is characterized by limited emesis but watery diarrhea progressing to bloody stools. Clinically, C. jejuni often mimics inflammatory bowel disease or appendicitis, given that pain is localized to the right lower quadrant.

D) INCORRECT:

Enteroviruses (including polio, coxsackie, and echoviruses) cause hand, foot, and mouth disease; aseptic meningitis; and herpangina, among other conditions — but they do not often cause gastroenteritis. The prefix “entero” is derived from the fact that this group of viruses replicate in the gastrointestinal tract.

E) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli O157:H7 classically causes profuse bloody diarrhea, often after ingestion of contaminated food. It can cause severe disease and has been associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

questions.text: A 42-year-old previously healthy patient presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of acute-onset nausea, vomiting, and watery nonbloody diarrhea following attendance at a community event. Multiple attendees have reported similar symptoms. Vital signs show mild tachycardia. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes but normal skin turgor and capillary refill. The patient reports decreased oral intake but is tolerating small sips of clear fluids without immediate vomiting. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Supportive care with oral rehydration and antiemetics
Intravenous fluid resuscitation and hospital admission
Clear liquid diet restriction until symptoms resolve

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Treatment for viral gastroenteritis is supportive, including fluid replacement, electrolyte repletion, and antiemetics. This patient has mild dehydration but can tolerate oral fluids, making oral rehydration with antiemetics the appropriate initial approach.

B) INCORRECT:

IV fluid resuscitation and admission are reserved for patients with severe gastroenteritis or signs of significant dehydration.

C) INCORRECT:

While nitazoxanide may reduce duration of illness, the evidence supporting its use is limited and it is not considered standard first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Diet restriction is not necessary if patients are able to tolerate oral intake.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not indicated for viral gastroenteritis and would be inappropriate for suspected norovirus infection. Ciprofloxacin is used for bacterial gastroenteritis, but this presentation is more consistent with viral etiology given the acute onset, watery diarrhea, and epidemiological factors.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a 16-hour history of vomiting and watery diarrhea. He reports decreased oral intake due to nausea and has had minimal urine output over the past 6 hours. His wife states that several residents at his assisted living facility developed similar symptoms 2 days ago. On examination, he appears lethargic with dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, and orthostatic hypotension. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with oral rehydration solution and antiemetics
Order abdominal CT scan to evaluate for complications
Prescribe nitazoxanide and schedule follow-up in 24 hours
Obtain stool culture and begin empiric ciprofloxacin
Administer IV fluids and consider hospital admission

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has signs of significant dehydration, including orthostatic hypotension, tachycardia, and decreased urine output. Discharge with oral rehydration is inappropriate because this patient is unable to maintain adequate oral intake and there is clinical evidence of volume depletion.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies are not indicated for typical viral gastroenteritis. CT scan would not change acute management priorities.

C) INCORRECT:

While nitazoxanide may reduce the duration of illness, evidence supporting its use is limited. More importantly, this patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation because of signs of significant dehydration, making outpatient management inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool culture is not routinely indicated for suspected norovirus gastroenteritis because confirmation does not affect management. Empiric antibiotics are not indicated for viral gastroenteritis and may worsen diarrheal symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has signs of significant dehydration and is at increased risk for complications given his age over 65 years and diabetes mellitus. IV fluid resuscitation and consideration for hospital admission are appropriate for patients with severe gastroenteritis or significant volume depletion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 24-hour history of nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps. He attended a large family reunion two days ago, and several other attendees have since reported similar symptoms. He denies any recent travel, antibiotic use, or bloody stools. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Different strains of Escherichia coli cause distinct diarrheal illnesses. Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a primary cause of traveler's diarrhea, but the patient denies recent travel. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli, such as O157:H7, typically causes bloody diarrhea and is associated with undercooked ground beef, which is not suggested here. Prominent vomiting in an outbreak setting is less typical for E. coli infections.

B) CORRECT:

Norovirus is the leading cause of acute gastroenteritis outbreaks in adults worldwide. It is highly contagious and characteristically spreads in settings with close person-to-person contact, such as family gatherings, cruise ships, and long-term care facilities. The incubation period is typically 12–48 hours, which aligns with the patient's symptom onset two days after the reunion. The clinical presentation of abrupt onset nausea, prominent vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps is classic for norovirus. The illness is usually self-limited, resolving within 1–3 days, and treatment is supportive with hydration.

C) INCORRECT:

Rotavirus causes a similar clinical picture of vomiting and watery diarrhea. However, it is the most common cause of severe gastroenteritis in infants and young children, not adults. Widespread childhood vaccination has significantly decreased its incidence. Although adults can be infected, it is a much less frequent cause of outbreaks in this population compared to other pathogens.

D) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is a common cause of bacterial foodborne illness, often associated with undercooked poultry. Although it can cause watery diarrhea, it frequently leads to an inflammatory colitis with fever, severe abdominal pain, and bloody stools, which are absent in this patient. The incubation period is also typically longer, ranging from 2 to 5 days.

E) INCORRECT:

Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite typically acquired from contaminated water. It causes a more subacute or chronic illness with a longer incubation period of 1–2 weeks. Symptoms include profuse, foul-smelling, greasy stools (steatorrhea), bloating, and flatulence. The acute onset of vomiting and rapid course described are not characteristic of giardiasis.
questions.hint: Transmission of this pathogen commonly occurs from person to person, especially in settings like cruise ships, nursing homes, and large family gatherings.
